answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Robert,
Numerous cities and towns have been using Peak Democracy Inc's Open Town Hall platform for citizen satisfaction surveys.  
One recent example is Loveland CO:   http://www.peakdemocracy.com/portals/170/Forum_480/Issue_1957 . 
The Open Town Hall platform integrates a suite of reporting and analysis tools - including real-time analysis by geography, demographics, affinity groups, relationship between comments, a clickable word cloud, etc. 
In your state of Virgina, there are several Peak Democracy clients including Arlington, Norfolk, Virginia Beach, Chesterfield, Williamsburg, and Alexandria is about to launch. 
To learn more, go to PeakDemocracy.com.
Mike

answers.author: Jesse Himes
answers.text:
Hi Robert,
Great question. I found a couple of resources that may help you on the Knowledge Network.
The Knowledge Network has a topic area dedicated to citizen surveys that has all kinds of great articles and other resources.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/45/Citizen_Surveys
The National Citizen Survey has been pretty popular among local governments as well. The following link has the details.
http://icma.org/en/results/management_strategies/leading_practices/data_driven_communities/national_citizen_survey
There’s also a great blog post that gives details about why it’s important to do citizen surveys and provides resources about how to conduct and implement them.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/blogs/blogpost/2172/Citizen_Surveys_Give_Your_Community_What_They_Want
Good luck and I hope these help!
Jesse Himes, Knowledge Network Intern, jhimes@icma.org

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
Robert, I would echo the positive comments here about the National Citizen Survey, developed in partnership with ICMA and the National Research Center.   While the NCS is not a "do it yourself" survey, it is proven methodology and also allows for benchmarking of results from local governments across the country.  Given the economy of scale reached by utilizing a survey that is widely used by local governments, you may find that the cost is reasonable for you. 
Additionally, I would echo the suggestion on the use of the Peak Democracy Open Town Hall product as another option for survey outreach to the community.    It is a different approach than the NCS, but offers a different kind of opportunity for you to consider.  
Information on both of these products can be found by visiting the Center for Management Strategies website at www.icma.org/strategies .  The National Citizen Survey information can be accessed at    http://icma.org/en/results/management_strategies/leading_practices/data_driven_communities/national_citizen_survey .
Information on the Open Town Hall product can be found at http://icma.org/en/results/management_strategies/leading_practices/civic_engagement/peak_democracy
